title: How to make a Dm13 chord, and what scale does it use - Quora

response.answer_text: Dm13 ≡ 1-♭3-(5)-♭7-(9)-(11)-13 = D-F-(A)-C-(E)-(G)-B. In guitar theory, notes in parentheses are optional. Sticking to guitar theory, which ignores inversions for chord-driven guitarist standardization purposes, an example finger position is X-X-0-5-6-7 = ●-●-D-C-F-B. Assuming you’re focusing on the diatonic scale, the underlying scale can only be C major, unless employing temporary accidentals in one or more measures. That said, guitar theorists commonly ignore changes to the structure of the underlying scale when building & naming chords, particularly extended & altered chords. For example, the underlying scale might be G major, even though our Dm13 chord requires an F rather than F♯. The parent scale, the one whose keynote double-dips as the chord’s root, is D major, not D minor. Your confusion about where B comes from is somewhat common among undergraduate students of music theory. Specifically, all chords, including minor, assume a major scale as its parent. So while the quality of the chord itself is minor, its parent scale is major.

There are two, non-competing, answers to this question. The first and simplest is that there are more than one type of minor scale. The Melodic Minor scale does indeed include a full 6th (which an octave higher is a 13th), and in the case of D melodic minor is a natural B. The second answer is less direct but equally important and useful: remember, every scale is associated with a series of chords, so, a D minor chord does not have to imply a D minor scale. In this case, for example, the D minor chord could be the 2nd degree chord in the C Major scale. The “scale” associated with that chord is the D Dorian, which is the second mode of the C Major scale. Simply put, it’s The C Major scale starting on the D note. Well, the C Major scale includes a natural B, so a D minor 13th chord is “in scale”. This second answer is where you should start, because the designation “13” implies there is also a b7, in this case a natural C.
